title: Why is the empty set considered a set? - Quora

response.answer_text: You ask why the empty set is considered to be a set. The answer is convenience. Three of the mathematicians who developed set theory were Dedekind, Cantor, and Peano. Two of them, Dedekind and Peano, required their sets to be nonempty, while Cantor considered the empty set to be a valid set. Why did it happen that Cantor’s position ended up being dominant? There are advantages to excluding the empty set and only accepting sets if they have at least one element. The advantages are similar to excluding 0 from numbers and only accepting positive numbers. For example, when Dedekind constructed real numbers from rational numbers, he used what we now call Dedekind cuts of rational numbers. A Dedekind cut of the set of rational numbers consists of partitioning the set of rational numbers into two nonempty subsets so that all the elements in one of those subsets are less than all the elements of the other subset. If you don’t consider the empty set to be a set, you can leave out the word “nonempty” in the definition of Dedekind cuts. So, for that and other reasons, it can be convenient to require sets to be non-empty. But there are advantages to including the empty set as being a set. The biggest one is that intersections of sets always exist. If you exclude the empty set as a set, then disjoint sets don’t have intersections, and that means every time you use intersections of sets, you have to consider two cases: the case where the sets are disjoint and don’t have an intersection, and the case where the sets are not disjoint and do have an intersection. Cantor had another reason as well to include empty sets. They worked out well in his theories of ordinal and cardinal numbers. Always having an intersection is enough of an advantage. Cantor’s position won out. Hilbert, Frege, Russell, and Zermelo all accepted the empty set. It’s not that set theory couldn’t be done excluding the empty set, but it would be much more complicated to exclude it than to include it. When it is actually required that a set needs to be nonempty, that can easily be done by including the word “nonempty”.

This question is similar to the question, “Why is 0 a number?” The answer is that you want to be able to subtract two numbers and get a number. What number is 4–4? The result is a number called zero. Given two sets A and B, the set A-B is the set of all elements that are in A but not in B. Thus, if you have a set and “subtract” the set A from itself, you get all elements of A which are not in A. Thus A-A is a set with nothing in it. The result must be a set with no elements, so in order to subtract one set from another, you need something with no elements, referred to as the empty set. You also need the empty set to take the intersection of two sets A and B, since it is possible that A and B have no elements in common (for example, if A is the even integers and B is the odd integers). So you need the empty set in order to say that the intersection of any two sets is a set. Your question used the phrase “an empty set.” There are of course many empty sets — for example, the set of all integers that are both even and odd, the set of apples on my table (take my word for this), the set of computers that always behave (that you can prove for yourself), the set of even prime numbers bigger than 2. All of these empty sets are different from one another, since each has its own definition. However, each of these empty sets has the same elements as each other empty set, so from a mathematical perspective all of these empty sets are the same. From a mathematical perspective, there is only one empty set. So, from a mathematical perspective, you should have used the phrase “the empty set” instead of “an empty set”. From a philosophical perspective, the examples I mentioned above are all different; after all, how can a set of apples equal a set of numbers? This reflects the perspective that the definition is “intentional” — that is, it is not the members of the set that are most important, but the kind of members that it has. The mathematical definition of a set is “extensional” — all that matters is what is in the set (its “extent”) not how the elements got there (its “intent”). This may be more than you wanted to know.

I am dissatisfied with the answers so far, as they amount to, “the empty set is a set because it is a set.” I would like to offer a more global perspective. Let's talk about categories. They are collections of objects, together with collections of morphisms between the objects. We can compose morphisms when they are end-to-end, and this composition is required to be associative. Lastly, each object in a category must have an identity morphism from it to itself, which doesn't tamper with other morphisms under composition. Now, a very useful and arguably the most quintessential category is the category of sets. Its objects are sets, and its morphisms are functions. Functions can of course be associatively composed, and each set has an identity function. The category of sets enjoys some very nice properties; it has all small limits and colimits (roughly speaking, any reasonable “equation” in the language of sets has a universal solution that is characterized by that “equation”), and in particular it has an initial and terminal object: every set receives precisely one morphism from the empty set (the null function), and every set offers precisely one function into any set with one element (they are all isomorphic, so who cares which we choose?). It has a swathe of other delightful and useful properties reflecting why sets can formalize mathematics, too: it is something called a Cartesian closed category, meaning it has a notion of an “object of morphisms” from one set to another (the set of functions), and the operation of currying exists, which lets us turn functions into function sets into functions out of products of sets. All of this would look quite different, if it were even still there, if we removed the empty set. We would still have statements saying how [math] (A^{B})^{C} \simeq A^{B\times C} [/math], but it wouldn't enjoy the same universal properties and overall things would be kind of broken. To fix things in light of removing the empty set, it would make sense to start requiring that every set be instead equipped with a fixed element it contains, and then require functions to preserve this basepoint. Doing this would give sets a different class of nice properties, but then we are left with questions such as, “why are sets commonly defined with a basepoint?” Another perspective is that sets act like domains of discourse for predicate logic. The category of sets is in fact dual to the category of complete atomic Boolean algebras; this means that any fact stated about sets reflects a fact about logic, and visa versa. The empty set reflects the fact that a statement can be false, and removing the empty set from set theory would in a sense trivialize its connection to logic. This even gets to the root of the Lambek-Curry-Howard correspondence, tying category theory, logic, and computer science together. The initial set didn't do anything wrong, and while its existence may be empty and pointless, it's certainly not useless!

A null set is an absolutely essential element of the set theory. Without it, mathematicians struggled (and repeatedly failed) in making the theory non-contradictory. Just like “0” is a number, so is null set a set. Null-set is the neutral element of the set theory - if you add it to another set, you get the “another” set. If I remember my Set theory course correctly (but it’s been 15 years+ and it wasn’t my favorite subject), the whole theory is built around the Null Set: You axiomatically define a Null set.Then you allow a set to contain a set as its element.You then declare that the “size” of a Set that contains a null set as its element is “1”. This gives you a meaning for the number “1”.You also define the operations for joining, intersecting and subtracting sets, and explain how the “size” of a set increases in each of those cases.And finally, you say that nothing is called a set if it wasn’t formed by (repeatedly) applying the previously defined rules.Since the above is simplified, I would’t advise anyone to use this as their sole resource for studying. Instead, you should read the proper axiomatic system, such as: Zermelo set theory - Wikipedia This was groundbreaking, because without such system, paradoxes were popping left and right (you probably heard those paradoxes such as “Imagine a SET which contains exactly those sets that don’t contain themselves. Does this set contain itself?”) The Set Theory does not allow such set to be formed and thus avoids the paradox.

It makes sense to define set theory starting with the existence of an empty set for reasons roughly similar to why it’s useful to have number systems which include zero as a core element of numeric sets. Even though these represent an “absense” of something, in a certain sense, they are important to help establish the logical foundations, the definitions and axioms from which number theory and set theory can be built. Several millennia ago, the understanding of numbers arose principally from commerce and the planning of major construction works. So it was common to have a basic knowledge of numbers, counting up to whatever was in the realm you’d need, with no need for an explicit “zero” value in those systems in the Western world (other cultures included the concept of “zero” in their mathematics). It wasn’t until the mid-nineteenth century that mathematicians went back and looked at number theory and arithmetic from the standpoint of pure logic and axioms. From the exploration of this topic, Peano’s Axioms were born: the logical foundation for all modern number theory, including arithmetic. Peano’s axioms can be summarized quite succinctly to establish the set of natural numbers (positive integers beginning with one), or as I’ll do the set of whole numbers, as I tend to refer to them (non-negative integers beginning with zero). 0 is a whole numberFor every natural number n, there is a succ(n) which is also a natural number. Thus for every natural number there is a successor. Thus succ(0)=1, succ(1)=2, and so on.succ(n)=0 is always false. That is, there is no natural number whose successor is zero; there is no predecessor of zero, in other words.Then there are several axioms I will skip over regarding equality and reflexivity as they willll clutter the discussion, but you can find them on Wikipedia[1] or Wolfram MathWorld.[2]From these axioms, you can build up the logical definitions of addition as repeated application of the succ(n) function, and from that you can define multiplication as repeated addition, and exponentiation as repeated multiplication. You can also define the “inverse” functions of these basic operators, such as subtraction, as in a–b, but we need to make sure that b≤a so subtraction is closed across the whole numbers, or b<a for subtraction to be closed over the natural numbers. And so on for division (thou shalt not divide by zero!) and so on… We also note that under those operators, zero behaves in a special manner under addition since it doesn’t change the value you’re adding it to; so it’s referred to as the additive identity. Similarly one is the multiplicative identity. Zero also has the special property that if you multiply anything by zero you get zero, so there are logical ramifications from that since you can’t “undo” multiplying by zero; there is no multiplicative inverse of zero which is where the “Thou shalt not divide by zero!” requirement comes from. All well and good, but how does this apply to set theory and the empty set? I’ve taken a considerably roundabout way to get to set theory, talking first about the logical foundations of number theory and arithmetic. But when Georg Cantor and Richard Dedekind laid out the foundations of modern set theory in 1870, they did so with a similar logical approach built upon core definitions and axioms. When you consider the union of sets, for example, in a sense that is roughly comparable to addition. We always end up with a set which has the same or higher cardinality (number of items in the set). So in the same way that zero becomes quite useful as an additive identity, the empty set is a useful concept since taking the union of any set with the empty set leaves the original set unchanged. In a similar fashion, set difference is roughly equivalent to arithmetic subtraction, but actually it’s a bit different. The set difference involves removing the elements which are common to both sets (the set intersection), and then the difference is what you are left with. Here, the empty set can be used in two ways: If you take the difference of any set with the empty set, you always end up with the original set unchanged. This is similar to a–0 = a in arithmetic terms. If you take the intersection of any set with the empty set, you always end up with the empty set. So this is analogous to a×0 = 0 in arithmetic terms. Once you are comfortable with these basic definitions and axioms, you begin to appreciate the existence of zero, and the existence of the empty set, as all of the theory is logically consistent and there are no surprises to be encountered. Yet both types of mathematical theory can lead to exciting explorations of complex phenomena and natural properties. The set of prime numbers, for example, which have known properties arising from the pure logic of Peano’s axioms. When folks encounter complex numbers, with the definition of this mysterious value equal to the square root of –1, folks tend to trip up on the idea that such a beast may exist (and it doesn’t help that mathematicians have dubbed this as an “imaginary” number). Once you are comfortable with that axiomatic definition as a way to extend the real number set and arithmetic operations, then complex numbers, which have imaginary components, become a powerful way to tackle new problems efficiently using these new, logically-consistent, arithmetic tools. So too, as you explore even higher branches of mathematics, such as group theory and abstract algebra as an example, you need to allow for the core definitions and axioms to exist, and then explore where each new branch of mathematics can go with from those logical foundations. Hope this helps; sorry that it may be a bit overlong. __________________________________________SOURCES [1] Peano axioms - Wikipedia [2] Peano's Axioms -- from Wolfram MathWorld

It took centuries to accept the idea that 0 is a number (and to accept to calculate with negative numbers). As the other answer says, it would be very complicated not to have an empty set to deal with.I’ll give you one example. Think of this nice little theorem which states that [math]\left|A\cup B\right|=\left|A\right|+\left|B\right|-\left|A\cap B\right|[/math] (where [math]\left|X\right|[/math] designates the number of elements of the set [math]X[/math] - or more generally it’s cardinal).  12 = 6+9–3 In plain English, the number of elements of the reunion of the sets [math]A[/math] and [math]B[/math] is the sum of the number of elements of these two sets minus the number of eléments in the intersection. It is quite obvious, as when you add the numbers of elements of the two sets, you count their common elements twice, so that you must substract the number of common elements to get the correct number of the union. If you did not have an empty set, you could not express it so nicely and simply. It would work only when there are common elements, et you would need a second theorem for the case when the sets [math]A[/math] and [math]B[/math] are disjoints. By the way, you can see om this example the correlation with the number 0… Coming back to the axiomatic theory of sets, a set is by definition defined by what elements are in the set or not. The first one to be constructed is precisely the empty set, and there is only one empty set. Moreover, there is one way to describe the theory where one assumes that all the sets can be constructed starting with the empty set, then the set containing the empty set as it’s only element, then all the sets you can build with those two first sets, and so on. The classical way to represent the natural numbers within set theoriy represents them as sets this way (and you obviously need the empty set to do it!): [math]0=\oslash,\,1=\left\{ 0\right\} =\left\{ \oslash\right\} ,\,2=\left\{ 0,1\right\} =\left\{ \oslash,\left\{ \oslash\right\} \right\} ,\,3=\left\{ 0,1,2\right\} =\left\{ \oslash,\left\{ \oslash\right\} ,\left\{ \oslash,\left\{ \oslash\right\} \right\} \right\}[/math], etc.

If you read the axioms of the Zermelo Franekel theory, then you’ll find that the existence of the empty set (….there exists a set which has no elements…..) is called the Axiom of Existence. And that’s where the answer to your question is hidden. After all whenever someone describes a new theory (or something similar), it’s their moral responsibility to ensure that they can make sense out of such a thing. In other words, they must not describe a theory of something which cannot exist (maybe because it’s existence can be refuted or otherwise). Now in the first place to provide the existence of a set it is needed to describe a set without making use of something that the theory plans to introduce, and thus a set that is not composed of anything — the set that has nothing (a.k.a. the empty set). Then one can play with this empty set and use axioms such as the axiom of union and the axiom of power sets to build “bigger” sets. Further the empty set is unique. Here’s a quick proof : Let A,B be two empty sets. Then the statement x belongs to A is false for each x (by each x I mean each x we can speak of) and by the ex falso quodlibet it follows that x belongs to A implies x belongs to B. And in a similar spirit we get : x belongs to B implies x belongs to A. And hence the axiom defining the equality of sets (Axiom of Extensionality in the Zermelo Fraenkel theory of sets) tells us that A and B are identical sets. Hence we conclude the uniqueness of the empty set.

The Empty Set. The set with no members. Because empty sets exist everywhere in mathematics. What is the set of natural numbers that are both even and odd? There are none. All natural numbers are either even or odd but none are both, therefore, the answer is the Empty Set. Because empty sets are used to prove properties of other sets and set operations. Given that A is a subset of B, what is the set of elements in A that are not in B? By the definition of subset, there are no elements of A that are not also in B. The answer is the Empty Set. Thus the empty set helps us prove containment. Given the Set of Irrational Numbers, what is the set intersection of the Irrational Numbers and the Integers? Since there are no numbers which are both Integers and Irrational Numbers, the answer is the Empty Set. Thus the empty set helps us prove disjoint-ness between sets. Given two parallel lines in the plane, what is the set of points of intersection in the plane between the two lines? Again, there are none, so the answer is the Empty Set. Geometric properties can be proven by constructing a set with no members. Being able to prove that the problem statement’s answer is the Empty Set is an important proof technique in Mathematics. The Empty Set is a very important set because of its property “I have no members” which has a rich and varied mathematical interpretation determined by context such as no solution to a set of equations, no points in common in the plane, no edges in common among sub graphs. It goes on and on …

One of the axioms of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory is that the empty set exists. Given the existence of a set allows one to use the other axioms, in particular, the power set axiom, to derive the existence of other sets. The empty set can also be used in the axiom of infinity to show that an infinite set exists. Another use for the empty set is that the operation of set intersection can be considered closed. That is, the intersection of any two sets, including those that are disjoint, is another set. The empty set can also be used to represent the number 0. It would be the set with no members.

Mathematicians define sets so that the empty set is a set because 1) it matches up with our intuition of what “set” means, and 2) it makes working with sets much simpler. Intuitively, a set may be thought of as a conceptual container. It is like a bag that can contain objects. Just as we can have an empty bag, we can also have an empty set. It is really quite natural. Nothing odd about it at all. What would be odd and cumbersome is defining sets in such a way that we are not allowed to have an empty set. It’s as if we want to talk about bags that can contain marbles, but we prohibit ourselves from talking about an empty bag. It ends up being quite awkward and arbitrary. For example, if I have a collection of 100 marbles, one way of specifying which of my marbles are contained in my bag is to indicate, for each marble, whether or not it is in the bag. For each marble, it is in the bag or not. Why should I be allowed to leave out any individual marble, but not allowed to leave out all of them?

Why is an empty set called a set? In most set theories, like ZFC, it’s axiomatic. In others, there’s usually an axiom saying every subclass (or entity containing some or all elements) of every set is itself set. Thus the subclass containing no elements is a set. You may then ask: why define set theory this way? As far as I can tell, there are a few answers. It keeps many operations on sets well-defined for all sets. Consider two disjoint sets, [math]A[/math] and [math]B[/math]. Consider also the familiar intersection operator [math]\cap : \mathbf{Set} \times \mathbf{Set} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set}[/math]. The only sensible value of [math]A \cap B[/math] is [math]\varnothing[/math].In the von Neumann construction of the ordinals, every ordinal is a set and each successor of a given number is its powerset. This makes the empty set a natural (ie: isomorphic to any other) choice for representing 0: there is no need to define other numbers by fiat.The empty set gives the categories [math]\mathbf{Set}[/math] of all sets and [math]\mathbf{Top}[/math] of all topological spaces strict initial objects, which is essential for keeping these categories cartesian closed, which makes their equational theories much nicer. This point is in some sense a generalization of the first.

The mathematical theory(ies) of set defines and describe objects called « sets ». Just as the Euclidean geometry defines points, line, squares and so on. There is rules that decides what a set is, but essentially a set is an object in which other objects are member of (in set theory, a set contains other sets). Take a set S, and an object o. We will note « o ∈ S » if o is a member of « S » and « o ∉ S » if o is not a member of S. For a set S, define « being empty » as the property that for all objects o , « o ∉ S » . Usually the rules of the theory of set imply that there is such an object. « S » exists, is defined by set theory, and is empty … it’s the empty set. Either there is proof that it exists, see ZF: (Formal) Proof of Empty Set from Separation or it’s an axiom that there is such an object Axiom of empty set - Wikipedia and you just say « there is an empty set ». An idea of proof could look like « you can always remove an object from a set and gain a new set ». Take a set that contains 5 elements. Remove one element, then remove one element from the obtained set. Repeat that. At some point you can’t remove anything, and you got a set from the operation of removal. You’ve got an set.

My little brother had trouble with the concept of empty sets when he was first learning about them in high school. This is how I explained it to him (this might not be entirely mathematical, kindly correct me if anything I say is not logical): A set is like a box with some stuff in it. It is a well defined collection of objects. When you look inside the box, you should be able to tell if something’s in it or not, there should be no ambiguity. Now let’s consider an empty set. It’s a set with nothing in it. So, it’s like an empty box. A box is still a box even if there’s nothing in it! I used this analogy because my brother was having trouble understanding why the cardinality of [math]\phi[/math] is 0, but the cardinality of [math]\{\phi\}[/math] is 1. In the first case, we have an empty box, so the number of items in it is 0. In the second case, you have an empty box inside a box. Now the number of items inside the (bigger) box is 1.

Why is an empty set a set? Semantics apart, essentially because it’s a convenient extension of the idea of sets with elements in them - just as zero is a convenient extension of the counting of things. Mathematics also has this rather strange convention that all empty sets are the same, regardless of context. By analogy, consider a load of baskets of fruit, but without any bananas; yes, we have no bananas - all these baskets are empty of bananas, even though they might contain the odd apple or orange (or grape) so are not per se empty. The set of {baskets with bananas in them} would be empty. But, there there are, different. Best not mention this to any mathematics teachers, though; they might get upset and start quoting text-books. The conventional theory is that all emptiness is the same. The notional ‘basket’ in set theory is intrinsic to the boundary of the set, though, it is not a separate woven thing. If the boundary in contained in the set - made up of things within the set - the set is closed; if not, the set is open (yes, there can be semi-open ‘soft’ sets). Because an open set has nothing in it that might be in it, ‘the’ empty set is therefore always open.

Because it would be jolly inconvenient were it not. In particular, given any two sets [math]A[/math] and [math]B[/math], I would want their intersection, [math]A\cap B[/math], always to be a set. Were it not there would be endless special cases to deal with [math]\ddot\smallfrown[/math] Having said that, there is nothing stopping you defining a new object, let’s call it a sset. Ssets have exactly the same properties as traditional sets except for the fact that they always contain at least one member. If you actually bother to define ssets like this, and start using them in your mathematics, you will quickly see why traditional sets have the Empty Set amongst their number.

The empty set needn’t have its own axiom. The axiom schemata of (restricted) comprehension implies its existence. Therefore, it has just as much ontological footing as subsets of very routine sets like the subset of all even natural numbers or the subset of all prime natural numbers. In other words, one single axiom implies both that the empty set exists and that the set of all even natural numbers exists. Perhaps why it is considered a set lies with us wanting to always have that the intersection of x and y exists (i.e., is a set). If our set theory is rich enough for more than one set, it is possible that x and y are disjoint (e.g., the set of even numbers intersected with the set of odd numbers). The intersection of disjoint sets can be safely regarded as the same type of thing as the two inputs for the binary relation whose output is their intersection: sets. Since the intersection of two disjoint sets is the empty set, something strange would happen with the intersection of x and y for two sets x and y: sometimes it would be a set and sometimes not, depending on whether they are disjoint. I guess its just either a nomenclature issue or a philosophical issue.

Why is an empty set considered a set? Why shouldn’t it be? If I have nothing in my bank account, why is it called my bank balance? A set is a collection of objects. If you don’t want to consider an empty collection, a collection that’s up to you. But there’s nothing wrong with calling it a collection. It’s just a word. And it’s convenient, it allows you to do algebra with sets in the same way you can do arithmetic and algebra with numbers. In fact the empty sets does the same job as zero does among numbers.

I assume you’re looking for an intuitive explanation, and not a romp through the details of ZFC or some other formal axiomatization of the set concept. If you have two sets, their intersection is itself a set. It has a nice unambiguous description, as the set of all elements in common to the two given sets. It shouldn’t be hard to conjure up two sets that you (or your audience) view as non-controversial, but which are disjoint. My go-to example in class: let E = the set of people who lived in the Eighteenth Century, and let T = the set of people who were at one time considered television stars. Their intersection is the set of television stars who were alive in the eighteenth century. Also known as the empty set. A more mathy example might be the set of all real solutions to the equation [math]\frac{1}{x} + 2 = \frac{4+2x}{x}[/math]
Well, it’s got the word ‘set’ in it, so it cannot be otherwise. It’s like asking ‘why is an empty trashcan a trashcan?’.

It's a bit like zero in relation to the natural numbers. There's nothing very natural about it, but the idea allowed us to conceive of the negative integers and the place value concept in the decimal system. With sets, we want to be able to define union and intersection operations, but without the empty set, intersections wouldn't always be defined. So I agree the notion of an empty set isn't something obvious or natural, but it is very useful. Hence we extend the concept to include a set without any elements.

Is the empty set a set? Is zero a number? For the reasons similar to it being useful to have zero as a number, it is useful to declare that the empty set is a set. It is progress that mathematics has made over the centuries. Two thousand years ago, we did not realize the usefulness of having a number zero. When the concept of “set” evolved, we immediately knew from our experience of the usefulness of having the number zero, that we should also declare the empty set to be a set.

The set that contains no element is a set. You can define the set by saying. For a given element X, X does not belong to the set. It is a set that always holds no element. The empty set is really useful in discrete math because it is the neutral element of union (empty set union another set is always another set) , but the absorbent element of intersection (empty set intersection another set is always empty set). Like the concept of 0 in natural numbers sometimes you need mathematical elements that allow you to represent properties of the domain.

It is technically convenient to include the empty set among sets, just as it is technically convenient to include zero among the natural numbers. If the empty collection were not admitted as a set, the intersection of two disjoint sets would not be defined. More importantly, we wouldn’t be able to generally assert that “if S is a set and P a well-defined property, there is a set consisting of exactly those elements of S that have property P”. We would have to make allowance for all sorts of exceptions.
A basket can hold items. A basket that has no items is still a basket, just without any items. Thus, an empty set is a set, just without any elements.

Why is zero a number? Why is the empty sequence a sequence? Difficult philosophical questions that people got really mad about some thousands of years ago. Luckily, we now understand these things much better. The definition of a set is that it's something that we can ask “do you have the element [math]x[/math]?” You can ask that question to the empty set. The answer is always “no”, but you can ask, and that's all that is needed to make it a set. It’s also a practical matter: many things get much simpler when zero is a number and the empty set is a set.

Think of it as some container or bag. An empty bag is still a bag. It might not have anything in it and it might not be as interesting as a bag that has things in it, but it’s still a bag. The same goes for an empty set. It’s a set just like any other set, it just has nothing in it.

Nothing speaks for not considering it and everything for considering it. You could exclude the empty set from the sets but things would become inconvenient. For example the axiom schema of specification: For every set z and for formula f(x) with one free variable x the set exists: { x | x is an element of z so that f(x) holds } Now if f(x) is the formula (property, predicate) “x is unequal to x”, then no element is ever selected into the subset, and thus the resulting set is always the empty set, irrespectively from the “z” we started from. If the empty set were not considered as a set, the unconvenience of having to spell out this exception would arise here and at other many places.

The collection that contains no members hasn’t always been taken to be a set; an interesting account of the early history of set theory that explains the developments that to led the fundamental notions accepted in contemporary set theory can be found here: http://math.bu.edu/people/aki/8.pdf.

If there is mathematics in another galaxy, they may choose to set up their terminology so that empty set is not a set. Then again, maybe they will not. The advantages of having empty set as a set is that it allows for a well-defined operation of intersection of subsets of a given set, as well as a complement to a subset. It is also nicer to have a set of [math]n[/math] elements have [math]2^n[/math] subsets rather than [math]2^n-1[/math]. So, don’t overthink it, it is just a convention, although a useful one.

Start with any set, take everything out if it, and you are left with an empty set. Hence the empty set is a subset of every set. ... An element of a set is one of the things in the set. A subset of a set is another set that does not contain any elements which are not elements of the set to which it is a subset. The empty set or null set is the unique set having no elements; its size or cardinality (count of elements in a set) is zero.

It’s the same reason why the number 0 is necessary to construct all numbers. For instance, how do we measure 5? Without zero, we don’t know where to count from. Should I start at -4? That would mean that the number 5 has a measure of nine. Zero is how we tell where to start from in order to count stuff, measure distance, and so on. Zero is also something that can be universally agreed upon as a good starting point. We all know that we need a way to represent that nothing is there. Likewise, you need a starting point for set theory. Where do we start from in order to get a good idea of how many elements are in the set? We need a starting point. Otherwise, we’d be screwed.

Because not having the empty set would be a pain in the ass. Without the empty set, we can’t intersect two disjoint sets. The expression { x : x in A where x satisfies P } is not valid if no elements of A satisfy P. Other answers mention ZFC. But it’s easy to come up with a “modified ZFC” where there is no empty set and our mathematical universe will still remain the same. Mathematicians define things to make life easier. The reason we have the empty set is the same reason that we have negative numbers, irrational numbers, and complex numbers. In principle, we can do everything with just positive integers, but why make life difficult?

I have an empty suitcase. I still call it a suitcase. More importantly, if the empty set wasn’t considered to be a set, we would have to make a whole lot of definitions and theorems in mathematics a lot more complicated, because we would need to add special cases and exceptions wherever a set could possibly be empty.

A set must have an unambiguous rule for determining, for any x, either Yes x does belong, or No x does not belong. An empty set has the simplest possible rule: the answer is always No. How could it be any more well-defined than that?

In that context, it describes a set of measure zero; such a set is not necessarily empty. Theempty set may also be called the void set.

There is no formal definition of a set, i.e. there is no test for sethood. Mathematicians have simply found that it is useful to assume that there exists an object [math]\emptyset[/math] such that, for all [math]x[/math], we have [math]x\notin \emptyset[/math].
Because it follows from the axioms of standard set theory (ZFC) that it is a set. However, it is easy to come up with a different set theory in which it is not a set.

One of the obvious ways that the empty set contributes to set theory is allowing closure under the operation of intersection. The binary operation performed on two sets will always yield a set. If you have two sets that have no elements in common, their intersection is the empty set.
